## ADDITIONAL MATHEMATICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 301, 154, 316]]<|/det|>
Paper 2  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[732, 277, 905, 293]]<|/det|>

2 hours

No additional materials are needed.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 418, 222, 433]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 435, 880, 604]]<|/det|>
INSTRUCTIONS- Answer all questions.- Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.- Write your answer to each question in the space provided.- Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- You should use a calculator where appropriate.- You must show all necessary working clearly; no marks will be given for unsupported answers from a calculator.- Give non-exact numerical answers correct to 3 significant figures, or 1 decimal place for angles in degrees, unless a different level of accuracy is specified in the question.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 634, 212, 648]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 650, 728, 682]]<|/det|>
INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 80.- The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[398, 73, 599, 89]]<|/det|>
Mathematical Formulae  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[437, 133, 561, 151]]<|/det|>
## 1. ALGEBRA  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 165, 240, 182]]<|/det|>
Quadratic Equation  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 194, 384, 212]]<|/det|>
For the equation \(ax^{2} + bx + c = 0\)  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[415, 212, 581, 247]]<|/det|>
\[x = \frac{-b\pm\sqrt{b^{2} - 4ac}}{2a}\]  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 271, 228, 288]]<|/det|>
Binomial Theorem  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[245, 291, 752, 330]]<|/det|>
\[(a + b)^{n} = a^{n} + \binom{n}{1} a^{n - 1}b + \binom{n}{2} a^{n - 2}b^{2} + \ldots +\binom{n}{r} a^{n - r}b^{r} + \ldots +b^{n}\]  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 345, 499, 381]]<|/det|>
where \(n\) is a positive integer and \(\binom{n}{r} = \frac{n!}{(n - r)!r!}\)  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 410, 384, 427]]<|/det|>
Arithmetic series \(u_{n} = a + (n - 1)d\)  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[245, 432, 534, 465]]<|/det|>
\[S_{n} = \frac{1}{2} n(a + l) = \frac{1}{2} n\left\{2a + (n - 1)d\right\}\]  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 488, 336, 504]]<|/det|>
Geometric series \(u_{n} = ar^{n - 1}\)  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[245, 509, 428, 579]]<|/det|>
\[S_{n} = \frac{a(1 - r^{n})}{1 - r} (r\neq 1)\] \[S_{\infty} = \frac{a}{1 - r} (|r|< 1)\]  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[401, 610, 594, 628]]<|/det|>
## 2. TRIGONOMETRY  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 643, 156, 660]]<|/det|>
Identities  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[415, 670, 583, 720]]<|/det|>
\[\begin{array}{c}{\sin^{2}A + \cos^{2}A = 1}\\ {\sec^{2}A = 1 + \tan^{2}A}\\ {\csc \sec^{2}A = 1 + \cot^{2}A} \end{array}\]  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 765, 242, 782]]<|/det|>
Formulae for \(\Delta ABC\)  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[403, 791, 594, 880]]<|/det|>
\[\frac{a}{\sin A} = \frac{b}{\sin B} = \frac{c}{\sin C\] \[a^{2} = b^{2} + c^{2} - 2bc\cos A\] \[\Delta = \frac{1}{2} bc\sin A\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 75, 94, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 74, 428, 92]]<|/det|>
Solve the equation \(\left|4x + 9\right| = \left|6 - 5x\right|\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 74, 920, 92]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 477, 97, 496]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 477, 892, 496]]<|/det|>
Find the values of the constant \(k\) for which the equation \(kx^{2} - 3(k + 1)x + 25 = 0\) has equal roots.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 492, 920, 510]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 94, 91]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 514, 900, 536]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows the graph of \(y = \mathrm{f}(x)\), where \(\mathrm{f}(x) = a(x + b)^2 (x + c)\) and \(a, b\) and \(c\) are integers.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 545, 144, 564]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 545, 437, 564]]<|/det|>

<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 700, 460, 718]]<|/det|>
Hence solve the inequality \(\mathrm{f}(x) \leqslant -1\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 700, 920, 718]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 79, 94, 98]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 920, 121]]<|/det|>
The curve \(\frac{4}{x^{2}} +\frac{5}{4y^{2}} = 1\) and the line \(x + 2y = 0\) intersect at two points. Find the exact distance between these points.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 103, 920, 123]]<|/det|>
<mark>[6]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 75, 96, 94]]<|/det|>
<label>5</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 75, 920, 111]]<|/det|>
A cube of side \(x \mathrm{cm}\) has surface area \(S \mathrm{cm}^2\). The volume, \(V \mathrm{cm}^3\), of the cube is increasing at a rate of \(480 \mathrm{cm}^3 \mathrm{s}^{- 1}\). Find, at the instant when \(V = 512\),

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 121, 146, 140]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 121, 346, 140]]<|/det|>
the rate of increase of \(x\),

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 121, 920, 140]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 470, 146, 488]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 470, 346, 488]]<|/det|>
the rate of increase of \(S\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 470, 920, 488]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<label>6</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 308, 920, 348]]<|/det|>
\(AOB\) is a sector of a circle with centre \(O\) and radius \(16\mathrm{cm}\). Angle \(AOB\) is \(\frac{2\pi}{7}\) radians. The point \(C\) lies on \(OB\) such that \(OC\) is of length \(7.5\mathrm{cm}\) and \(AC\) is a straight line.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 358, 143, 377]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 358, 470, 377]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 359, 920, 377]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 662, 146, 681]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 662, 428, 681]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 662, 920, 681]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<label>7</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 75, 623, 95]]<|/det|>
A curve has equation \(y = \mathrm{p}(x)\), where \(\mathrm{p}(x) = x^{3} - 4x^{2} + 6x - 1\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 106, 144, 125]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 106, 920, 141]]<|/det|>
Find the equation of the tangent to the curve at the point (3, 8). Give your answer in the form \(y = mx + c\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 121, 920, 140]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 515, 144, 535]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 515, 180, 535]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 515, 920, 552]]<|/det|>
Given that \(\mathrm{p}^{- 1}\) exists, write down the gradient of the tangent to the curve \(y = \mathrm{p}^{- 1}(x)\) at the point (8, 3).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 532, 920, 551]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 657, 180, 675]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 656, 740, 676]]<|/det|>
Find the coordinates of the point of intersection of these two tangents.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 656, 920, 675]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 72, 96, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>8</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 71, 920, 91]]<|/det|>
A photographer takes 12 different photographs. There are 3 of sunsets, 4 of oceans, and 5 of mountains.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 102, 146, 121]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 102, 539, 121]]<|/det|>
The photographs are arranged in a line on a wall.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 133, 180, 152]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 133, 747, 152]]<|/det|>
How many possible arrangements are there if there are no restrictions?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 133, 920, 152]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 244, 181, 262]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 243, 920, 278]]<|/det|>
How many possible arrangements are there if the first photograph is of a sunset and the last photograph is of an ocean?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 260, 920, 279]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 384, 180, 402]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 384, 920, 418]]<|/det|>
How many possible arrangements are there if all the photographs of mountains are next to each other?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 400, 920, 419]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 490, 146, 510]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 490, 636, 510]]<|/det|>
Three of the photographs are to be selected for a competition.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 522, 181, 541]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 522, 920, 541]]<|/det|>
Find the number of different possible selections if no photograph of a sunset is chosen.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 522, 920, 541]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 647, 181, 665]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 645, 920, 680]]<|/det|>
Find the number of different possible selections if one photograph of each type (sunset, ocean, mountain) is chosen.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 662, 920, 681]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 81, 99, 101]]<|/det|>
<label>9</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 81, 143, 100]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 73, 920, 120]]<|/det|>
In the expansion of \(\left(2k - \frac{x}{k}\right)^5\), where \(k\) is a constant, the coefficient of \(x^2\) is 160. Find the value of \(k\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 98, 920, 117]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 540, 144, 559]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 540, 180, 559]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 536, 920, 574]]<|/det|>
Find, in ascending powers of \(x\), the first 3 terms in the expansion of \(\left(1 + 3x\right)^6\), simplifying the coefficient of each term.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 552, 920, 571]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 78, 180, 97]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 75, 855, 101]]<|/det|>
When \(\left(1 + 3x\right)^{6}\left(a + x\right)^{2}\) is written in ascending powers of \(x\), the first three terms are

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 97, 756, 119]]<|/det|>
\(4 + 68x + bx^{2}\) , where \(a\) and \(b\) are constants. Find the value of \(a\) and of \(b\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 100, 920, 118]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 84, 104, 103]]<|/det|>
<label>10</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 75, 628, 106]]<|/det|>
The function f is defined by \(\mathrm{f}(x) = \frac{\sqrt{4x^2 - 1}}{2x}\) for \(0.5 \leqslant x \leqslant 1.5\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 114, 440, 134]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows a sketch of \(y = \mathrm{f}(x)\).

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[235, 149, 749, 420]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 439, 144, 457]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 439, 180, 457]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 437, 670, 457]]<|/det|>
It is given that \(\mathrm{f}^{-1}\) exists. Find the domain and range of \(\mathrm{f}^{-1}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 439, 920, 457]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 75, 180, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 73, 433, 92]]<|/det|>
Find an expression for \(\mathrm{f}^{-1}(x)\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 75, 920, 92]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 616, 146, 635]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 606, 917, 650]]<|/det|>
The function g is defined by \(\mathrm{g}(x) = \mathrm{e}^{x^2}\) for all real \(x\). Show that \(\mathrm{gf}(x) = \mathrm{e}^{\left(1 - \frac{a}{bx^2}\right)}\), where \(a\) and \(b\) are integers.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 631, 920, 650]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 73, 144, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 73, 181, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 73, 579, 92]]<|/det|>
Differentiate \(y = \tan (3x + 1)\) with respect to \(x\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 72, 920, 91]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 256, 180, 275]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 247, 520, 293]]<|/det|>
Hence find \(\int_{\frac{\pi}{12}}^{\frac{\pi}{10}} \left( \frac{\sec^2(3x + 1)}{2} - \sin x \right) \mathrm{d}x\) .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 257, 920, 276]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 104, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>12</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 72, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
A particle \(P\) travels in a straight line so that, \(t\) seconds after passing through a fixed point \(O\), its velocity, \(v \mathrm{ms}^{- 1}\), is given by

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[272, 114, 495, 141]]<|/det|>
\[\nu = \frac{t}{2\mathrm{e}}\qquad \mathrm{for} 0\leqslant t\leqslant 2,\]

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[272, 160, 470, 183]]<|/det|>
\[\nu = \mathrm{e}^{-\frac{t}{2}}\qquad \mathrm{for} t > 2.\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 196, 920, 229]]<|/det|>
Given that, after leaving \(O\), particle \(P\) is never at rest, find the distance it travels between \(t = 1\) and \(t = 3\). [6]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 214, 920, 231]]<|/det|>
<mark>[6]
